Description: Dell Inc. agreed to pay $100 million to settle allegations of failing to disclose material information to investors and using fraudulent accounting to make it falsely appear that the company was consistently meeting Wall Street earnings targets and reducing its operating expenses.

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Description: An Austin financing company, Dell Financial Services, has paid $63,294 in back wages after an investigation by the U.S. Department of Labor found the company did not pay 22 accounting and financial workers proper overtime wages.
Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division

Description: EMC Corporation paid the United States $87.5 million to settle a lawsuit alleging that the information technology company violated the False Claims Act and the federal Anti-kickback Act. Specifically, the United States had alleged that the company represented during contract negotiations that, for each government order under the contract, EMC would conduct a price comparison to ensure that the government received the lowest price provided to any of the company's commercial customers making a comparable purchase. According to the government's complaint, EMC knew that it was not capable of conducting such a comparison, and so EMC's representations during the negotiations as well as its subsequent representations to GSA that it was conducting the comparisons were false or fraudulent.

Notes: Source document obtained through a Freedom of Information Act request to the agency.

Company: VMware Inc. and Carahsoft Technology Corporation
Description: VMware Inc. and Carahsoft Technology Corporation agreed to pay $75.5 million to resolve allegations that they violated the False Claims Act by misrepresenting their commercial pricing practices and overcharging the government on VMware software products and related services.
Illinois Wage Payment and Collection Act
Info Source: Contained in data obtained on April 18, 2017 in response to an Illinois Freedom of Information Act request.
Contained in data obtained on April 11, 2017 in response to an open records request.

Agency: Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs

Description: The settlement consisted for $8 million in economic damages and $1.1 million in legal fees.

Dell and its subsidiary Dell Financial Services agreed to pay the Attorney General's Office $4 million in restitution, penalties and costs to resolve charges of fraudulent and deceptive business practices that scammed consumers across New York State.

Dell agreed to pay $1.5 million in customer restitution and $1.85 million to the states to settle multistate litigation arising out of problems with the company's financing promotions, rebate offers, technical support and repair policies.
EMC Corp., a subsidiary of Dell Technologies, agreed to pay $110,000 as part of a settlement of allegations it discriminated against a transgender woman.

Agency: Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs
